title-group.article-title: Development of a Direct Injection Spark Ignition Engine Test for Injector Fouling

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2004 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: Direct Injection Spark Ignition (DISI) engines are known to be sensitive to injector fouling. To evaluate the effectiveness of detergent additives and the influence of fuel parameters on injector fouling, a new DISI engine test has been developed, using a 2.0 I stoichiometric homogeneous DI engine on a test bench. Severe engine running conditions have been found to lead to a high amount of deposits on the injector nozzle over a short period of time ("one day" procedure). Injector fouling is measured using a fuel flow measurement procedure representative of injector operating conditions (opening time and pressure). This procedure has proved to be reliable and repeatable with different gasoline fuels and additives being evaluated. The influence of the base fuel and the effect of the composition and the dosages levels of detergent additives (keep-clean and clean-up properties) are demonstrated with the test method.

ref.mixed-citation: Allen A. Aradi, Bill Imoehl, Noyes L. Avery, Paul P. Wells and Richard W. Grosser : "The Effect of Fuel Composition and Engine Operating Parameters on Injector Deposits in a High- Pressure Direct Injection Gasoline (DIG) Research Engine", 1999-01-3690, SAE Technical Paper.
Masao Kinoshita, Akinori Saito, Souichi Matsushita, Hitoshi Shibata, Yutaka Niwa : "Study of deposit formation mechanism on gasoline injection nozzle", JSAE 98 35429, Technical Notes.
David C. Arters, William J. Dimitrakis AND Malcolm J. Macduff : "Injector Fouling in Direct Injection Gasoline Vehicles", 2000 Fuels and Lubes Asia Publications.

Allen A. Aradi, William j. Colucci, Herbert M. Scull Jr., and Martin J. Openshaw : "A Study of Fuel Additives for Direct Injection Gasoline (DIG) Injector Deposit Control", 2000-01-2020, SAE Technical Paper.

Noma Kazutoshi, et al (OACIS Deposit Work Group) "A Study of Injector Deposits, Combustion Chamber Deposits (CCD) and Intake Valve Deposits (IVD) in Direct injection Spark Ignition (DISI) Engines", SP 2002-SP-1719, JSAE Technical Paper.
